metadata.titleEn: Chronological and environmental index data set of Wenchuan  loess profile in Western Sichuan Plateau
metadata.description: This data is the chronological, grain size and bulk density data of loess-paleosol sequence in Wenchuan (WCH) in the eastern Tibetan Plateau. We measured the median grain size and bulk density data of the profile (10m) at intervals of 2.5cm and 5cm respectively. The OSL dating experiment was carried out in the Luminescence Dating Laboratory of the Key Laboratory of Western China’s Environmental Systems (Ministry of Education) in Lanzhou University. AMS 14C measurements  were carried out at Peking University. The experimental analysis of environmental indicators was also completed at the Key Laboratory of Western China’s Environmental Systems (Ministry of Education) in Lanzhou University. The OSL ages were determined by an automated Risø TL/OSL DA-20 reader. The grain size data were measured by a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser diffractometer; the bulk density data were determined by the oil-soaked method. This data provides the detailed chronological data of loess-paleosol sequence and the variation characteristics of grain size and bulk density since the last glacial period in the eastern Tibetan Plateau, and provides an important data reference for understanding paleoclimate evolution and dust accumulation history in the eastern Tibetan Plateau.
metadata.instructions: The chronology data , grain size data and bulk density data of Wenchuan (WCH) section are stored in CSV format. The names of the files are "chronology data of WCH section" and "grain size and bulk density data of WCH section". The data sheet can be viewed and edited with Excel software in Microsoft office

literatureList.titleEn: Chronology and dust mass accumulation history of the Wenchuan loess on eastern Tibetan Plateau since the last glacial.
literatureList.referenceEn: Liu, L., Yang, S., Cheng, T., Liu, X., Luo, Y., Liu, N., Chen, H., Chen, Z., Li, P., & Liu, W. (2021). Chronology and dust mass accumulation history of the Wenchuan loess on eastern Tibetan Plateau since the last glacial. Aeolian Research 53, 100748.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain chronological and environmental indicators in loess-soil sequences on the eastern Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: One data collection method involves measuring grain size and bulk density at intervals of 2.5-5 cm over a 10-meter section of loess-soil sequences. Chronological data is obtained through optically stimulated luminescence dating using a Risø TL/OSL DA-20 luminescence analyzer, while grain size is measured with a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser particle size analyzer, and bulk density is determined using the oil immersion method. Additionally, AMS14C dating is conducted at Peking University.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific characteristics and methods used for measuring grain size and bulk density in a dataset related to loess-soil sequences on the eastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: Grain size measured using Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser particle size analyzer, bulk density determined by oil immersion method, measurements at intervals of 2.5-5 cm for a 10-meter profile

Quantification.Question: What is the interval measurement used for grain size and bulk density data collection in the loess-soil sequence dataset from the eastern Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using optical stimulated luminescence in determining the age of loess-paleosol sequences?
Definition.Answer: Optical stimulated luminescence (OSL) is used to determine the age of loess-paleosol sequences by measuring the last time mineral grains were exposed to sunlight. In this domain, OSL dating provides detailed chronological data for the loess-paleosol sequences from the Tibetan Plateau region since the Last Glacial Period.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the choice of specific measurement intervals, such as 2.5-5 cm, when collecting soil profile data in regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The choice of specific measurement intervals, such as 2.5-5 cm, is influenced by the need for detailed resolution in capturing variations in grain size and bulk density within the loess-soil sequences. This high-resolution approach allows researchers to accurately track changes over the last glacial period and understand the environmental and climatic history of the eastern Tibetan Plateau.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to collect detailed chronological and environmental indicator data from loess-paleosol sequences on the eastern Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting detailed chronological and environmental indicator data from loess-paleosol sequences on the eastern Tibetan Plateau provides important data reference for understanding the historical dust accumulation, paleoenvironments, and paleoclimate research in the region since the last glacial period.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methodological steps involved in measuring grain size and bulk density for loess-paleosol sequences in the context of Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Grain size and bulk density for loess-paleosol sequences are measured at intervals of 2.5-5 cm using specific laboratory equipment. Grain size is determined using a Malvern Mastersizer 2000 laser particle sizer, while bulk density is measured using the oil immersion method. These measurements are conducted to provide detailed chronological data and to analyze the variations in grain size and bulk density characteristics since the last glacial period.
